subject.translation[0].definitions[0].de: the thing you are talking about or considering in a conversation, discussion, book, film etc
subject.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Paul has strong opinions on most subjects.
The subjects covered in this chapter are exercise and nutrition.
While we’re on the subject of money, do you have the $10 you owe me?
Truffaut’s childhood memories were the subject of his first film.
subject.translation[0].definitions[1].de: an area of knowledge that you study at a school or university
subject.translation[0].definitions[2].de: the thing or person that you show when you paint a picture, take a photograph etc
subject.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Monet loved to use gardens as his subjects.
subject.translation[0].definitions[3].de: a person or animal that is used in a test or experiment
subject.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: The subjects of this experiment were all men aged 18–35.
subject.translation[0].definitions[4].de: a noun, noun phrase, or pronoun that usually comes before a main verb and represents the person or thing that performs the action of the verb, or about which something is stated, for example ‘she’ in ‘She hit John’ or ‘elephants’ in ‘Elephants are big’
subject.translation[0].definitions[5].de: someone who was born in a country that has a king or queen, or someone who has a right to live there

subject.translation[1].definitions[0].de: a subject country, state, people etc are strictly governed by another country
subject.translation[2].definitions[0].de: to force a country or group of people to be ruled by you, and control them very strictly
subject.translation[3].definitions[0].de: used to say that something is affected, or can be affected, by something
subject.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: Withdrawals are subject to a withholding tax of between 10% and 30%.
Dealers convicted of felony charges will be subject to suspension.
subject.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: The proposed transaction is subject to shareholder approval.
A deal has been struck, subject to contract (=it is not final until the contract has been signed).
subject.translation[3].definitions[2].de: used in insurance contracts to describe a situation in which a property has been insured for less than its real value, and the insured person has to pay for part of any loss
subject.translation[3].definitions[2].ex: In the event of under-insurance, the settlement would be subject to average.
